title: How to Buy Many Video Games for Less Than $100 a Year

steps.headline: Buy used video games; never buy new ones.
steps.description: New copies of games always mean more expensive prices. So consider buying used copies.

steps.headline: Write down how much you are willing or could afford to pay for one single game.
steps.description: Doing this will help you not accidentally over spend more than you could really afford.

steps.headline: Try to see if the game store you regularly go to have some sort of discount card.
steps.description: Some popular game stores like Gamestop have a cheap Edge card that you could use to buy used pre-owned games and have a 10% discount, Thus saving you money in the process.

steps.headline: Consider trading your games if you know where or who you could trade it in for.
steps.description: You could save money and get more games for this.

steps.headline: Wait till boxing days, Christmas times or in store specials.
steps.description: Many stores might offer some sort of special offer during special occasions and you could sometimes save a bundle.

steps.headline: Asks for them as gifts.
steps.description: Sometimes your family members might be willing to buy you video games as a gift. This works best if you were still a preteen or young teen.

steps.headline: Consider getting something called an odd job.
steps.description: Such as mowing lawns, Water someone's plants, walk someone's dogs or feed pets while the owners were gone. This will help you get the money you possibly need to get the game you want.

steps.headline: Look for the last generation games.
steps.description: Like if you are a PS3 or a Xbox 360 fan, consider buying the past generation games like PS2 and xbox games. Some very popular titles are not available for the current consoles and a lot of those games are dirt cheap as well.

steps.headline: Only buy the games you will consider liking.
steps.description: There's no point on buying the games you already knew you will not enjoy because then you'll ended wasting your money.

steps.headline: Actually play the games you had bought for a while.
steps.description: One way to save money on games is to actually play them for a while before buying more.

steps.headline: Consider checking out different stores instead of only focusing on one store.
steps.description: Many stores might be selling other games for a cheaper price so consider shopping at more than one location.

steps.headline: Split the game cost with someone.
steps.description: If you are willing to share a game with someone, consider buying the game with someone and determine a proper timetable for you and your friends. Doing this will keep costs down.

steps.headline: Wait for a while for a price drop.
steps.description: Most games will have sort sort of price drop after it's initial release. So consider buying them after it gets cheaper.
